**Youngest Person to Reach South Pole Solo: Scott Sears Completes 702-Mile Trek**

Scott Sears, a 27-year-old lieutenant in the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles, has become the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo, completing a 702-mile trek in just 38 days. Sears, brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, pulled a sled and supplies through 150mph winds and temperatures of -50c, reaching the pole on Christmas Day, 12 days ahead of schedule.

The journey was not without its challenges, with Sears describing hitting a wall on Christmas Eve, feeling like he couldn't take another step. However, after a brief rest, he was back on his way, fueled by juice, biltong, chocolate, and music on his iPod.

Sears' feat has raised over £33,500 for the Gurkha Welfare Trust to help rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, which were destroyed in the 2015 earthquake. He has also been praised by Andy Murray's mother, Judy, who tweeted congratulations on his achievement.

Sears' trek was not only a personal challenge but also a testament to his physical and mental endurance. He spent five weeks alone in a tent, facing extreme weather conditions and navigating crevasses and glaciers. Despite the challenges, Sears remains proud of his achievement, saying it will take a few weeks for everything to sink in.

Sears' journey has also sparked interest from the Guinness Book of Records, with the organization yet to confirm whether his feat will make it into the record books. Regardless, Sears' achievement is an impressive one, and he has earned widespread recognition for his bravery and determination.
answers: While many people were unwrapping gifts on Christmas Day, the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray was wrapping up a 700-mile, 38-day journey through brutally cold temps and blistering winds—and, he hopes, setting a world record. Scott Sears, 27, reached the South Pole on Monday, and he says he's the youngest person ever to do so solo, though Guinness has yet to offer its final seal of approval, the BBC notes. "MERRY CHRISTMAS FROM THE SOUTH POLE! Absolutely chuffed to pieces," he wrote on his blog, where he documented his unassisted adventure, which included temperatures of minus 58 degrees and wind gusts of up to 150mph. Sears said he was so tired when he finally took a rest after his trek that he fell asleep "within about 2 minutes of my head hitting the mat." Sears, whose sister, Kim, is married to the tennis star, describes a grueling expedition with icy, crevasse-marred terrain and an isolation made worse when the "iPod poltergeist" would occasionally strike, causing his music player to stop working. He says he "truly hit a wall" on Christmas Eve, where "everything was just saying 'no more, not one more step.'" But he devoured some dried meat, juice, and chocolate and pushed through, even hanging up his stinky socks as "makeshift stockings" for Santa that night. Title: It's Time to Take Our Daughters to the C-Suite

Companies need to do more to inspire women to lead, rather than blaming the lack of women leaders on an "ambition gap."

Introducing girls to a company's highest-ranking women can make a huge difference, as 80% of girls want to interact with successful women but 60% have not been offered the opportunity.

Girls also need to understand what leadership is like on a day-to-day basis. They need to know how executives motivate teams, solve complex financial problems, and develop new products. Making leadership more tangible can help resolve issues such as girls feeling uncomfortable trying to lead or not thinking they are cut out for leadership.

Princeton University's efforts to move women into leadership roles are a model for other institutions. The university found that the number of female students winning top academic honors and holding visible leadership roles had declined over the last decade. In response, the faculty started proactively encouraging female students to apply for academic prizes, resulting in 3 out of 4 Princeton Rhodes Scholars being women in 2011.

In conclusion, simply showing our daughters what an office looks like is no longer enough. Real breakthroughs will come when we bring girls inside the halls of power. We need to take our daughters into the C-Suite now so they can lead in the future.

The virus, closely related to Ebola, is a hemorrhagic fever that can have a high death rate. The patient's brother has developed symptoms similar to Marburg, and 80 people who came into contact with the victim have been quarantined, including 60 health-care workers.

**Symptoms and Transmission**

Marburg has an incubation period of five to 10 days, and symptoms include severe headache, myalgia, fever, and chills. The virus is spread through direct contact with the blood, tissues, or bodily fluids of an infected person or animal, such as fruit bats.

**Previous Outbreaks**

Marburg has been linked to several outbreaks in the past, including a 1967 outbreak in Germany and Yugoslavia, and a 1998 outbreak in Uganda that infected 154 people and killed 128. Another large outbreak in Angola infected 252 people and killed 227 in 2004.

**Treatment and Prevention**

There is no specific treatment for Marburg, but hospitalized patients can receive general supportive therapy. Experimental treatments are being developed, and Uganda has experience in controlling outbreaks of similar diseases.

**Uganda's Response**

Uganda's Prime Minister, Dr. Ruhakana Rugunda, has assured that the country has put in place rigorous surveillance and disease control measures to prevent a large-scale outbreak. The World Health Organization has been informed, and Uganda has experience in dealing with similar health threats.

**Conclusion**

While Marburg is a deadly virus, it is not particularly easy to catch, and if an outbreak is identified early and controlled, it is unlikely to escalate like the current Ebola outbreak in West Africa. Uganda's response to the outbreak has been swift and effective, and the country's experience in controlling similar outbreaks gives confidence that the situation can be brought under control.
